Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Transport properties and morphology associated with bursting-bubble induced jetting phenomena

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Bird, James
Proposal Number: 1351466

The proposed CAREER project is focused on understanding the physic al mechanism of the generation of aerosol droplets as bubbles burst. Understanding the physics behind submicron aerosol formation is important in a host of engineering applications ranging from turbine corrosion to the dispersion of respiratory deceases, since their residence time in the atmosphere can be on the order of weeks.
Intellectual Merit:
When a bubble bursts, a set of droplets is formed and these droplets break into other smaller droplets, the larger of which break up further creating a hierarchy of droplet sizes. Ultimately, submicron aerosol droplets are formed that are not predicted with current fluid dynamic models, since the primary physical mechanism responsible for their formation is unknown. The goal of this proposal is to explore three concepts on how jet drops from small bursting bubbles may account for observed submicron aerosols. One concept is that the empirical formulas that relate the size of millimeter bubbles to the size of jet drops that they produce may not be valid for micron-scale bubbles. Another concept is that satellite and sub-satellite droplets may develop when larger droplets are produced, and that these smaller droplets may account for the unexplained submicron aerosols. The final concept is that larger bubble-induced jets may couple with smaller jet drops or satellite drops and propel the smaller drops beyond the viscous sublayer. The PI will explore and evaluate these ideas using direct highspeed observations, numerical simulations, and appropriately dimensionalized experimental models.
Broader Impacts:

Results from the proposed work can find important applications with significant economic and societal impact, for example avoiding corrosion due to salt aerosols in sensors and engines operating in marine environments. Other applications on a local scale include modeling the airborne flux of aerosolized pathogens, such as bevotoxins from red tides to make better public policy decisions, such as which beaches to close. On a global scale, a better understanding of aerosol production is necessary to reduce uncertainty in global climate models, and will allow policy makers to better assess the risks and rewards of geoengineering mitigation strategies, such as deliberately injecting large amounts of sulfur particulates in to the atmosphere in hopes to counter the warming effects of greenhouse gases.
The proposal also includes outreach and education activities that are complementary to the research project. It is proposed to develop workshops for pre-service Early Childhood Education teachers and intensive laboratory immersion experiences for seasoned in-service elementary and preschool teachers. Finally, the proposal includes a partnership with the Boston Museum of Science to develop new science modules that aim to increase scientific engagement between children and their parents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every time a wave breaks, a toilet flushes, or raindrop hits the ground, numerous microscopic air bubbles are created. These bubbles rise to the water surface, sit for a moment, and then pop. When these bubbles pop, surface tension causes a tiny jet of water to be propelled into the air. This jet can break up into liquid droplets - referred to as jet drops - that can transport particulates in the water, such as sea-salt or microbes, into the atmosphere. The transfer of sea-salt and other cloud-condensation nuclei from jet drops into the atmosphere is believed to have a significant role in climate dynamics, as these aerosols cool the planet by scattering light and seeding clouds. Additionally, when bubbles burst in contaminated water sources, bacteria and other pathogens can be inhaled, which can lead to infection and fatal illnesses. The primary goal of this NSF-sponsored project has been to better understand and predict the sizes of jet drops formed from bursting bubbles. Emphasis has been placed on the smallest drops - those smaller than ten microns - as these drops have the largest impact in the applications above because they are light enough to be lofted high into the atmosphere and can be inhaled deep into the respiratory tract.

Not all bubbles will create jet drops when they rupture. One outcome of this project is a better prediction and understanding of which ones will. Past experiments and theory predicted that jet drop production would be inhibited by either viscous or gravitational effects. However, while there are a number of studies focusing on these two limiting cases, it was unclear how the production of jet drops would be affected under conditions when both gravitational and viscous effects were relevant. We identified a set of conditions in which jet drops do not form, counter to expectations, and demonstrate that this phenomenon can be attributed to a coupling between the gravity, effecting the bubble shape, and liquid viscosity. 

Another outcome relates the size and number of jet drops produced for the smallest bubbles. Past research disagreed on the size relationship between the jet drops and the bubbles that produced them for the smallest jet drops. The research from this grant provides clarity on the conditions that lead to the smallest top jet drops from bursting bubbles and the number of jet drops produced. A combination of systematic experiments and simulations demonstrated that the minimum size for the top jet drop is approximately 1% of the size of the initial bubble. We were able to attribute the minimum size to a confluence of two counteracting processes: viscous stresses before jet formation decrease drop size by sharpening a self-similar shape factor and viscous stresses after jet formation increase drop size by increasing the jet growth time. One consequence of these results is that the smallest top jet drop sizes for bubbles in water would be approximately 100 nanometers. Given that scientists have indirectly measured smaller aerosols, their source is likely elsewhere. One possibility that our project explored is that those smaller aerosols could be from satellite drops that can occur during drop breakup.

An additional aim and outcome related to the conditions when satellite drops form. These small droplets appear when a thin liquid thread develops and breaks up faster than its ends fully retract. Typically, this process is modeled by perturbing a cylindrical liquid thread with an amplitude that is small relative to the cylinder diameter. Yet early on in the pinch-off process, the ends of the liquid thread are conical and lack a characteristic length scale from which to normalize a finite perturbation. For this project, we numerically simulated the retraction of conical filaments and introduce self-similar perturbations that can enable breakup without biasing a particular length scale. We show that a critical perturbation amplitude is needed for droplets to form and that this amplitude can be accurately predicted by an argument based on the static stability of the initial perturbed cone. 

A final research outcome relates to microbes enriched and spread by droplets. The concentration of microbes and other particulates is frequently enriched in the droplets produced by bursting bubbles. We observed that the enrichment factor strongly depends on the film thickness at rupture, and developed a physical model, based on scavenging and drainage, that is consistent with our observations.

The project also included broader impacts that were complementary to the research. In particular, the project provided annual outreach experiences in which we brought pre-service early education teachers and art students into our lab to explore inquiry-based learning around the theme of high-speed photography of drops and bubbles. Finally, the project included a partnership with the Museum of Science in Boston that developed and tested a guided module using bursting bubbles to engage children and their caregivers in scientific inquiry.
